Yes, because AOSD is one of my central research topics.

1. The research papers CFP should be in 80-column plain text when distributed to the mailing lists. There are still people who uses old-good mail clients, whom should not be ignored.
2. I prefer a joint CFP for workshops submissions. I\'m usually forwarding those CFPs to local mailing lists, but very reluctant to do when I received 10 CFPs in a week.

AOSD and Middleware
AOSD and Software Architecture
AOP and Dynamic Environments

The printed program was the best organised conference program I have ever seen. Everything was accessible straight away.

Choose better panels. The panel this time was really disappointing...

Ideas:
\"AOSD for Web Technologies\" --- e.g., applying tools for JSP, Spring, ...
Repeat Wes Isberg\'s tutorial on \"AOP Idioms\" (?) from Lancaster
A tutorial on Batory\'s AHEAD work --- not just FOP in general, but the AHEAD tools in particular. Or some other toolset that can manage aspects across multiple languages/artifacts.
A tutorial on using AOSD/AOP for security concerns
Full catered lunch included in registration

Program is already excellent.
A topic that needs more attention in the technical track is formal methods relating to AOSD.

Web site is quite good, but needs more links at \"higher level\" pages. For example, there are few enough workshops and tutorials that they could be listed on a second-level page or even the top page, as oppoed to two clicks down ((top) -> program -> tutorials (-> ...)).
Local info is excellent and much appreciated!

Bonn facilities were quite good, though I had occasional problems with the wireless network. Lecture halls were sometimes noisy.
It would be good to hold workshops in room with moveable chairs and tables, so that people can organize themselves as they want, e.g., in break-out sessions).

USENIX Association conferences: USENIX, OSDI, ...
The O\'Reilly (and other) conferences on open source
Conceivably, via magazine advertising in Java trade magazines --- but these ads are quite expensive (~$15K), so it would be difficult to recover the cost
Yes. Exciting and promising area; conference is an excellent networking opportunity; good combination of researchers, students, and practitioners.

The AOSD 2006 organizing committee did an excellent job. The student event on Sunday was especially good and should be repeated in the future.
I previously submitted a paper evaluation at the conference. Some of my fill-in-the-blank answers on this form are new. I\'ll let you worry about how you want to count the multiple-choice answers!
Full catered lunch included in registration

The conference needs to take a much broader view of AOSD. The papers were largely about ad hoc, incremental extensions to existing approaches and were quite uninspiring. The industry talks about applications were very inspiring.
Yes, the networking opportunities are outstanding. AOSD is becoming friendly like OOPSLA, but on a more personal scale.
The local organizers and student volunteers were amazing. AOSD.06 was by far the best run conferences I have attended.

The research track needs to improve drastically, or I will probably not attend, unless it is in the neighbourhood (as it was now). Some of the papers reported on \"programming projects with AOSD\" level, and not on a real solid scientific level. The exception to this rule are the language-related papers, which were always really good. But the software engineering side of the papers was very weak ...

Yes, for those really interested in AOSD. Forum for reasearchers and industry partners; not too small, not too huge; great opportunity to meet people from different countries.
Good idea to keep: present 1-minute description for demos after the keynote speaker. Revisit the panel idea; I left with the sensation I lost my time there.

Encourage speakers to give better talks - find a room that allows them to be seen properly!
Quick Registration with bag at hotel was brilliant. Just Great!
I was generally underwhelmed by the quality of the talks. I am unlikely to attend again without a paper to present.

The banquet entertainment was the worst I have ever experienced at a conferece. I found it excruciating. Just giving Gregor a couple of beers and letting him reminisce (perhaps along the lines of Larry Wall\'s Perl state of the onion speeches at every Perl conference) would be a great improvement.

Other hotel listed on the accommodation page

I found the research program partly disappointing, in particular the paper about \"relationship aspects\", which felt like \"we take a two years old idea (see \'association aspects\' on AOSD 04), implement it again but this time much worse and less flexible and sell it as being new just because it uses AspectJ 5\". I really did not get how such a paper could be accepted - was just a waste of time.
Also I found the overlapping of tutorials and workshops quite unfortunate because I think that really a lot of people would have liked to attend both. Registration fees for tutorials were too high, in particular for students!
Also there seemed to be demand for a workshop on \"Logic based poointcuts\". It should be worthwhile considering this as a satellite event for next year.

I was astonished that when I came to the registration site, they did not have my badge ready and I had to give the all the information again which I had previously entered into the online registration form already. Why?
The location was quite good, really.
Definetely, because still a lot of good research was shown and it has just the right size to do efficient networking.

I found it a bit sag that students had to by a banquet ticket for 80 Euros, because this is certainly an amount which no student can easily afford. Also, students usually are forced by their university to register as students, which means they are not paid for a ticket, which then in turn basically means that they are unable to attend, and hence students are practically excluded from the banquet. (I know, this does not count for student volunteers but this should be no argument.) So my proposal would be to either include the banquet ticket fee within the student registration fee as for a usual registration (because then university is gonna pay) or to make the banquet / social event cheaper in general.
Full catered lunch included in registration
Found it expensive as I could only spend 1 day there. For the whole week I think the price is ok.
Full catered lunch included in registration
Less AspectJ, more broader issues of future generation programming languages

The problem with this years program was not the range of topics, but more the quality of the papers presented.

Better reviewing.
For example the following paper was very very poor, and should certainly have been rejected.
Using Aspects to Support the Software Process: XP over Eclipse Oren Mishali, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Israel Shmuel Katz, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Israel
Next year\'s program chairs should seriously consider if the people responsible for reviewing that paper in 2006 should be in the 2007 program committee again.

A reason to avoid AOSD is that there is too much evangelism, and not enough objective content.
This was one of the problems with the panel.
AOSD is almost twice as expensive as ICSE. The registration fee was way too high.
Sandwich lunches included in registration with $100 reduction in fee
The web site and the registration process were excellent.
AOSD 2006 was one of the best run and supported conferences that I have attended.
The keynotes were very good. Both addressed topics not covered elsewhere in the program. Both were thought-provoking and entertaining.

Yes, to anyone working with anything related to AOSD. Opportunities to get feedback, useful contacts, interesting ideas, assessing how AOSD is progressing.
